Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Cold Air Pool Exchange Processes during the Utah Wintertime Fine Particulate Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Persistent cold-air pools are a phenomena where air is effectively trapped in a basin or valley during high pressure events in wintertime. They are especially prevalent in high altitude basins in the western United States. One of the impacts of cold air pools is that particulate pollutants accumulate and affect the air quality for places like Salt Lake City, Utah. This award provides funding for researchers to take surface-based meteorological measurements during an existing aircraft-based air quality field campaign to better detail the processes that affect air movement within the cold air pools and impact the relevant chemical processes. In Salt Lake City alone there are over 1 million people affected by these events, and the research results may extend to other locations with similar topography such as Los Angeles and the Front Range of Colorado.

The researchers will join the NOAA-led Utah Wintertime Fine Particulate Study which will take place in Jan-Feb 2017 in the Salt Lake City region. The NSF-funded researchers will augment the air quality focused study with meteorological measurements of the persistent cold pools that set up in the valleys and basins of Utah in the wintertime. In cold air pooling events vertical mixing is inhibited and particulate pollutants accumulate and affect human health. Multiple ceilometers, a lidar, sodar, temperature sensors, a surface flux station, and radiosonde launches will be deployed as ground-based assets to complement the NOAA aircraft campaign. The deployment will target key processes and questions regarding atmospheric mixing and airmass exchange that affect chemical composition and chemical pathways of particulate air pollution formation. The specific processes include: 1) vertical mixing within the persistent cold-air pool, 2) nighttime injections of clean, but oxidant-rich air along the basin sidewalls and through down-canyon flows, 3) daytime ventilation processes along the basin sidewalls, and 4) airmass exhanges with the lake boundary layer of the Great Salt Lake.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every winter, population centers in mountainous areas suffer under high levels of particulate pollution that exceed the Ambient National Air Quality Standard (NAAQS). These pollution episodes occur when anthropogenic (i.e. man-made) emissions are trapped under meteorological conditions called Persistent Cold-Air Pools (PCAPs). These are initiated under anticyclonic conditions (i.e. under atmospheric high pressure) when warm air is moving above colder air. The cold air is then trapped in topographic basins. As emissions accumulate in the trapped and stagnant air, chemical conversions can lead to a buildup of fine particulate matter with diameters below 2.5 micrometers (PM2.5), which has well-documented adverse health effects.

Previous NSF-funded research, the Persistent Cold-Air Pool Study (PCAPS) has investigated the meteorological processes the lead to the buildup and removal of the air layers that accumulate pollution. In the present study, focused on the Salt Lake Valley, Utah, we not only document the key evolutionary stages of the PCAPs, but also investigate the smaller-scale processes at the edge of the PCAPs that can modulate PM2.5 concentrations within the polluted air mass. We take advantage of the improved observational network of air quality sensors to elucidate the impact of meteorological exchange and transport processes on air pollution concentrations. These exchange processes include (1) canyon breezes that exchange air through the tributary canyons entering the larger polluted basins, and  (2) the air exchange with the near-surface air residing over the Great Salt Lake that has different characteristics (as it is in contact with the lake water surface and thus can be warmer or colder than the Salt Lake Valley cold pool).

This RAPID award funded the summarized meteorological observations and analysis to augment the much larger air chemistry-focused and NOAA funded Utah Winter Fine Particulate Study (UWFPS), and made it possible to investigate the complex interactions between meteorological and air-chemistry processes. Sites instrumented with wind, PM2.5, and ozone sensors are shown in Figure 1.

The 2016-2017 winter season saw seven (7) pollution episodes with elevated PM2.5 concentrations, but during only three (3) of the episodes the 24-hour moving average of PM2.5 concentration at the key Salt Lake Valley monitoring site (Hawthorne Elementary) exceeded the NAAQI of 35 ug/m3.  All episodes occurred when the valley atmosphere was dominated by a PCAP. The strength of the trapping of cold air in a basin can be expressed by the Valley Heat Deficit (VHD), a measure of the amount of energy that would be needed to bring a valley or basin atmosphere to a neutral stratification. Under neutral atmospheric conditions, air is no longer trapped and can be readily mixed. Figure 2 shows the time series of the potential temperatures at the Salt Lake Basin bottom and top, as well as the time series of the VHD and the 24-hr average PM2.5 concentration at Hawthorne, emphasizing the connection between PCAPs and pollution episodes.

To investigate the influence of canyon flows on local air quality, we analyzed wind speed, wind direction, PM2.5, and ozone concentrations measured during the development of the pollution episodes. Figure 3 shows an example. We found that nighttime concentrations of PM2.5 are greatly reduced during clear nights as down-valley flows bring less polluted air to the mouths of tributary canyons. While PM2.5 concentrations are reduced, we generally saw an increase of ozone. Ozone is an oxidant that is normally depleted during pollution episodes as it reacts with NOx, a pollutant that accumulates in the PCAP. This finding is interesting, as the role of ozone in the process to produce nitric acid, a direct precursor of ammonium nitrate (and thus the main PM2.5 constituent) is unknown.

We also analyzed wind profiles near the lake-land interface to investigate the role of lake breezes (similar to land and sea breezes along a coastline) in modulating the concentrations of PM2.5 and ozone. We were able to document cases where less polluted air is blown in from the Great Salt Lake during the daytime during the onset of long pollution episodes. On the other hand we saw that cold and polluted air above the lake can more easily resist mixing with approaching weather systems. Sometimes this air can bleed back into the lowest parts of the Salt Lake Valley and lead to very strong spatial variations in PM2.5 concentrations.


This research project demonstrated that spatial variations in pollution concentrations are indeed caused by the exchange processes investigated and challenge decision making processes (e.g. outdoor school recess, sporting events, etc.) based on single regulatory monitoring sites. These initial finding further led the Utah Division of Air Quality to include pollution transport as a research priority.
